attributes.action: Ignore the petition to scrap the alleged "proposed Road Pricing car tax"
attributes.action_prefix: We the undersigned petition the Prime Minister to
attributes.background:
A round-robin email has excited much interest in the petition to scrap the alleged road pricing car tax.

The email contains several inaccuracies and wild, unsubstantiated claims and was designed to get people to sign a petition without thinking. (And it was very successful at doing so).

Vehicle taxation is here to stay - whether we like it or not. That is not the issue here. The issue is whether Government policy should be decided on many gullible people being scared into signing a petition by an email containing many untruths.

The email claims, inter alia, "The tracking device will cost about £200 and in a recent study by the BBC,
the lowest monthly bill was £28 for a rural florist and £194 for a delivery
driver. A non working mother who used the car to take the kids to school
paid £86 in one month." Has anyone asked the BBC when they carried out this study?

reasons: Duplicate - this is similar to and/or overlaps with an existing petition or petitions
